item.title: Beattie Reports on Nokor China
item.media:description: Q&A McKinley & Beattie / Nokor China / Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Hong Lei said China is in close touch with North Korea on the issue of a detained Chinese fishing boat urging Pyongyang to "deal with this as soon as possible" and protect the fishermen's legal rights and personal and property safety. A Chinese official says the private vessel from Dalian City in China's northeast Liaoning province was "grabbed" by North Korea earlier this month (May 5) in waters between the two countries. The vessel reportedly has a crew of 16 and Pyongyang has demanded a $100,000 payment for their release. Australian National University senior lecturer Michael McKinley tells Victor Beattie such incidents may show either disarray within the North Korean leadership or a rise in bilateral tensions
item.media:text: Q&A McKinley & Beattie / Nokor China / Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Hong Lei said China is in close touch with North Korea on the issue of a detained Chinese fishing boat urging Pyongyang to "deal with this as soon as possible" and protect the fishermen's legal rights and personal and property safety. A Chinese official says the private vessel from Dalian City in China's northeast Liaoning province was "grabbed" by North Korea earlier this month (May 5) in waters between the two countries. The vessel reportedly has a crew of 16 and Pyongyang has demanded a $100,000 payment for their release. Australian National University senior lecturer Michael McKinley tells Victor Beattie such incidents may show either disarray within the North Korean leadership or a rise in bilateral tensions

item.title: Williams Reports on Bangladesh Burma
item.media:description: Q&A Williams & Mildren / Bangladesh Burma / The United Nations says it is working with the governments of Bangladesh and Burma to prepare their disaster response procedures ahead of a cyclone. The U.N. said late Tuesday Cyclone Mahasen is expected to make landfall late Friday north of the Bangladeshi city of Chittagong, near the Burmese border. The international agency said there are "fears" Mahasen "could threaten millions of people" in northeast India, Bangladesh, and Burma's Rakhine State, where tens of thousands of internally displaced people are currently living in temporary shelters. Kirsten Mildren is the regional communications officer with the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs. Speaking from Bangkok, she tells VOA’s Sarah Williams about the efforts to prepare for the storm.

item.title: Beattie Report on US Burma
item.media:description: Q&A Wilson & Beattie / US Burma / Former Australian diplomat to Burma Trevor Wilson tells Victor Beattie such a U.S. visit would be the culmination of previous trips by the Burmese leader to other key trading partners.
item.media:text: Q&A Wilson & Beattie / US Burma / Former Australian diplomat to Burma Trevor Wilson tells Victor Beattie such a U.S. visit would be the culmination of previous trips by the Burmese leader to other key trading partners.

item.title: Beattie Reports on US Burma
item.media:description: Q&A Dahgaypaw & Beattie / US Burma / Such a U.S. visit by Burma's leader stirs disappointment among rights activists, including Myra Dahgaypaw of the group U.S. Campaign for Burma. She spoke with Victor Beattie
item.media:text: Q&A Dahgaypaw & Beattie / US Burma / Such a U.S. visit by Burma's leader stirs disappointment among rights activists, including Myra Dahgaypaw of the group U.S. Campaign for Burma. She spoke with Victor Beattie

item.title: Beattie Report on US Burma
item.media:description: Q&A Tin Maung Htoo & Beattie / US Burma / state television has announced that President Thein Sein will travel to the United States next week. The trip will reportedly include a visit with U-S President Barack Obama at the White House next Monday. U.S. officials have not publicly confirmed the visit, which follows President Obama's historic trip to Burma last November. Thein Sein was permitted to travel to New York to attend the opening session of the U.N. General Assembly session last September. The last Burmese leader to visit Washington was Ne Win NAY WIHN in 1966, nearly 50 years ago. Tin Maung Htoo, of the non-governmental organization Canadian Friends of Burma tells Victor Beattie, while Burma seeks a deeper economic relationship, the trip could prove useful for Washington seeking to counterbalance China's growing influence in Burma.

item.title: International Edition 14:30:00 GMT
item.media:description: Thirty-minutes of in-depth world news, plus highlights of the day's business and sports. Updated 10 times a day.

item.title: International Edition 13:30:00 GMT
item.media:description: Thirty-minutes of in-depth world news, plus highlights of the day's business and sports. Updated 10 times a day.

item.title: Inquiry
item.media:description: A light-hearted, laughter filled show that takes a look at everyday life - everything from where to find the best street food, to African comedy and storytelling, to the impact of cell phones on modern life.

item.title: In One Pakistan Province, Women Determined to Vote
item.media:description: Women make up roughly half of Pakistan’s population, but their participation in national elections in the southwestern province of Baluchistan historically has been much lower. Sharon Behn reports that, this time, women are determined to make a difference in the May 11 vote for a new national assembly.

item.title: Sonny Side of Sports
item.media:description: VOA's Sonny Young brings you the latest sports news and trends as well as questions and comments from sports fans around the continent.
